awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a High Resolution X-ray Computed Tomography Instrument for a Multi-User Imaging Facility
awd_abstract_narration:
This project acquires a high-resolution scanner that can obtain detailed 3D images at the micron or sub-micron level of a broad range of samples (ranging from biological specimens to biomaterials to 3D printed objects to soil samples) without destroying or altering the sample. This investment supports some research communities in natural and biological structures, and advanced multi-user research in several departments.  Projects are being carried out with the instrument in the areas of biology, chemistry, geology and cybersecurity for 3D manufacturing.  The resources will be shared by researchers from the university and local small biotech and pharmaceutical industries.
 
The system replaces a 12-year-old micro Computational Tomography (micro-CT) unit, which will be relocated to a new facility on the Newark campus of the university. Investigators from the campus have been using the facility, but are hindered by the current location in Piscataway, requiring traveling to and from the facility for the projects that do not require the higher resolution, lower scanning times, and temperature controlled scanning conditions associated with the nano-CT to be acquired. The investigators are thus leveraging the purchase of a SkyScan 1272 nano-CT for Piscataway researchers that require its capabilities to extend micro-CT imaging resources to the Newark campus. This multi-user imaging facility will be managed by full-time staff having multimodal imaging expertise. The nano-CT system will become one of five complementary imaging modalities available at Rutgers University mult-iuser Molecular Imaging Center (RUMIC).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcome Report 2022

     The SkyScan 1272 continues to be an integral imaging system at the multimodal imaging facility at Rutgers University. Over the 3-year project period, the imaging group has used the system to scan over 950 individual samples received from over 40 different research groups from the University as well as from the greater academic community and from clients from the biotech and consumer products sectors, totaling nearly 1900 hours of actual scan time. The system was used to scan samples as varied as isolated mammalian tissues, dental samples, biomaterials, soils, insects, plant roots and fish skulls.

     Throughout the project period the SkyScan 1272 has also contributed to the academic environment greatly. It promoted collaboration and made major contributions to the progress of projects and the scientific productivity of numerous research groups, resulting in at least three (3) posters, 1 virtual presentation, 6 scientific papers and 3 thesis dissertations. Most recently (Oct 2021) the imaging group presented two posters at the annual Pioneers in Endocrinology Workshop, at Rutgers University. One poster presented images of salmon otoliths (calciferous structures of the ear) generated using the SkyScan 1272. Discussion around the poster, involving researchers with similar interests, is expected to result in a multi-PI grant submission to relevant funding agencies focusing on basic questions related to the effect of environmental conditions on the growth and development of wild and farm-raised Atlantic salmon. In addition, a slide presentation of the results of this project was also presented at the virtual 2021 microCT User Meeting sponsored by Bruker Imaging Technologies Inc, the manufacturer of the SkyScan 1272.

     Over the last 2 years of the project period the imaging group has been involved with the development and optimization of contrast agent staining methods which have had a major impact on the quality of images generated by the SkyScan 1272. The methods enhance the resolution of submicron structures in samples that are important to the success to various projects including those involving the characterization of stress-induced developmental defects in 4-day-old zebrafish larvae and imaging endpoints in rat embryos exposed in utero to environmental particulate pollutants.  

     The commitment of the University for maintaining the operation of the SkyScan 1272 remains great. For example, this year the University purchased a broad license for the use of the iLab Laboratory Management System to better manage the operations of the Imaging Center and other core facilities. This system greatly facilitates many aspects of the management of the imaging systems, such as the SkyScan 1272, including scan scheduling, billing, tracking and revenue report generation. This iLab system has already improved the efficiency of the imaging staff which enables an increase in throughput to better support the userbase. In addition, the University recently approved funds to install 10Gbps fiberoptic computer lines, replacing the current 1Gbps lines, in the Imaging Center which will increase data transfer speeds between the SkyScan 1272 and remote workstations as well as enhance imaging processing and analysis speeds. 

     The acquisition of the SkyScan 1272 enabled the relocation of the SkyScan 1172 to a satellite image facility located on the Newark Campus 40 miles from the central imaging facility. This unit has now been slated to become an imaging resource in the Advanced Preclinical Imaging Laboratory (APIL) which is currently under construction in the vivarium of the Rutgers Medical Sciences Building in Newark. The APIL will house a PET/SPECT/CT imager, a high-resolution ultrasound, an optical imaging as well as the SkyScan 1172. In this way Rutgers can consolidate multimodal imaging resources to a centralized location and make them available to more researchers in the upcoming years. 

     The University and Imaging Team is appreciative of the NSF funding supporting the purchase of the SkyScan 1272 and are pleased with the successful completion of the project without any further actions or supplemental funding.    

 


Last Modified: 01/24/2022
Modified by: Edward J Yurkow
